metadata.titleEn: Glacier runoff segmentation data set in the five river source areas of the Qinghai Tibet Plateau (1971-2015)
metadata.description: The Qinghai Tibet Plateau is known as the "Asian water tower", and its runoff, as an important and easily accessible water resource, supports the production and life of billions of people around, and supports the diversity of ecosystems. Accurately estimating the runoff of the Qinghai Tibet Plateau and revealing the variation law of runoff are conducive to water resources management and disaster risk avoidance in the plateau and its surrounding areas. The glacier runoff segmentation data set covers the five river source areas of the Qinghai Tibet Plateau from 1971 to 2015, with a time resolution of year by year, covering the five river source areas of the Qinghai Tibet Plateau (the source of the Yellow River, the source of the Yangtze River, the source of the Lancang River, the source of the Nujiang River, and the source of the Yarlung Zangbo River), and the spatial resolution is the watershed. Based on multi-source remote sensing and measured data, it is simulated using the distributed hydrological model vic-cas coupled with the glacier module, The simulation results are verified with the measured data of the station, and all the data are subject to quality control.
metadata.instructions: Runoff segmentation data is stored in xlsx format and can be opened and read by office software such as office.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the data collection method used to estimate glacier runoff in the source regions of major rivers on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau?
Feature Specification.Answer: multi-source remote sensing, measured data, distributed hydrological model VIC-CAS, glacier module, simulation, validation with site-measured data, temporal resolution yearly from 1971 to 2015, spatial resolution by watershed, quality control processes

Quantification.Question: What is the temporal resolution of the data collection method used to estimate glacier runoff in river source areas on the Tibetan Plateau?

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential impacts on data accuracy and quality when using a distributed hydrological model coupled with a glacier module, based on multi-source remote sensing and measured data, for estimating runoff in large river source regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing a distributed hydrological model coupled with a glacier module, based on multi-source remote sensing and measured data, can enhance the accuracy of runoff estimation in large river source regions by integrating diverse data inputs and refining the simulation of glacier-influenced hydrological processes. These methods are validated using site-measured data and undergo quality control, likely resulting in more reliable and precise datasets for water resource management and disaster risk reduction in the Tibetan Plateau and surrounding areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the aim of developing a dataset that segments glacier runoff sources in the major river basins of the Tibetan Plateau from 1971 to 2015?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to accurately estimate the runoff in the Tibetan Plateau, reveal the patterns of runoff changes, and facilitate water resource management and disaster risk avoidance in the plateau and surrounding regions.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies can be employed to accurately simulate glacier runoff using distributed hydrological models in the source regions of major Asian rivers?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To accurately simulate glacier runoff in the source regions of major Asian rivers, a distributed hydrological model like VIC-CAS can be used. This approach involves coupling glacier modules with the model to account for the glacier dynamics. The process includes using multi-source remote sensing data along with actual measurements from monitoring stations to validate the simulation results. Quality control is performed on all collected data to ensure accuracy and reliability over the period from 1971 to 2015, with an annual time resolution and a spatial resolution focused on river basins.

Enablement.Question: What data collection methods enable the accurate estimation of glacier runoff in the major river source regions of the Tibetan Plateau from 1971 to 2015?
Enablement.Answer: The accurate estimation of glacier runoff in the major river source regions of the Tibetan Plateau from 1971 to 2015 is enabled by using a distributed hydrological model, VIC-CAS, which is coupled with a glacier module. This model utilizes a combination of multi-source remote sensing data and in-situ measurements. The model's simulation results are validated with observed data, and all data undergo quality control processes.
